What does it say that Elon and Tesla get more praise for promises of something they've yet to deliver, meanwhile, THE ENTIRE TIME THIS EXISTED. I just found out, today, a year later, Telsa is still rated level 2 autonomy. Waymo already stopped even testing level 3 over 5 years ago.

Tesla and Waymo systems are not even really comparable here... One only works in pre mapped specific area with bunch of extremely expensive sensors while the other works on any road without a need to premmap with just a few cameras. 
And those autonomy levels are just that, numbers on paper, those don't really represent actual capabilities of the system, it only represents what responsibility company takes for any accidents which could happen.
In other words, Waymo is more stable because its more or less hard coded for specific roads, Tesla is a universal system which will have more issues as its been built to work on any road. Waymo will win on short run, but will loose on long one. This is why even after all these years Waymo is still limited to small areas in just a handful cities , because it simply doesn't scale...

Dear Derek,

I highly respect your work, I have learned an enormous amount from your videos. That being said, I'd like to raise a couple of points which I find you have ignored in this video.


12:22 and 13:00
The question you have raised is only part of the whole story. A major issue with driverless cars is responsibility. No matter how bad a driver you are, if you cause an accident, you take the responsibility for it: you personally get fined, charged, locked up in jail, whatever. However, when (and it's a question of "when", not "if"!) a driverless car causes a serious accident, who will assume responsibility? The manufacturer? What would that even mean? They get fined? So what? That'd be essentially assigning a price tag to human life. This is very serious ethical question that must be addressed by the society.

Let us not pretend to not see the enormous economic interest of car manufacturers here. They are all pushing for driverless cars because for them it would mean that they can replace ALL existing cars with a new one. We are talking about trillions of dollars here, the business of the century. This is markedly different from aviation, for example: I highly doubt that any airplane was thrown out off the window just because it was not equipped with an automated pilot. I think this concerns many people, and comments like yours that the real ethical question is why not to have a driverless car are pretty out-of-the-line for this reason. Don't get me wrong, driverless cars can be a wonderful additional technology for humanity. But I think FORCING it on society is unacceptable. 

Also, among all people you should be very well aware of the dangers in making humans independent on premature technologies. Aviation is a fairly simple problem compared to a complicated traffic situation in the middle of a city. We are very reasonable to question whether the technology is safe and developed enough. There is a reason why intertia in technology exists in critical applications. Why do you think the entire financial system runs on software written in COBOL? Why many nuclear power plants have DOS-based software (!), or why the international space station does not use the latest version of MS Windows (or any version of Windows for that matter. They use Debian Linux, for a good reason...)?

13:20
Come on... How do we check these claims? Why on Earth should we believe Google saying this? This is exactly what EVERY company says when they want to sell a product. How many examples shall I enlist here where entire societies have been tricked by corporations just to win a few billions of dollars? As for Waymo's studies: again, due to the extremely high economic interest, why should we believe ANY of them? Let us ask the authorities instead!

They may be good for replacing taxis in a limited pre-mapped area, but they will never be able to replace driver-owned cars, which need to be able to travel anywhere (without HD mapping). Truly unrestricted self-driving is far harder than Waymo realizes, and their tiny fleet of glorified trolleys are keeping them blind to the mountain of technical challenges that lie ahead (in exchange for money now üí∞)

If they truly care about improving road safety, then they need to be able to replace the millions of privately owned vehicles that are already on the road. But with Waymo‚Äôs business model that will never happen, because the vehicles and their sensors are too expensive for anything other than a high-usage taxi service.

(I actually fully agree that self-driving technology is far safer than people realize. For instance, many laypeople seem to have the misguided idea that the goal should be literally zero self-driving accidents, yet we could be preventing millions of accidents with today‚Äôs technology. However, due to the sponsorship, you did not ask enough meaningful questions to prove this idea to your audience, which kind of defeats the purpose of covering this topic in the first place)

I'm surprised nobody ever brings up the what I see as the elephant in the room-- Insurance and liability. States differ in the way they require drivers to insure their vehicles. Here in Florida, we "no fault" insurance-- I call it "your fault" insurance, because that's kind of what it is-- Everything is your fault. Each person assumes their share of the liability. The big cost in our insurance because of that is the PIP, or "Personal Injury Protection", because basically you have to be insured proportionate to the worst driver on the road, which makes insurance expensive here, but I digress...

We live in such a litigious society, and I know this sounds awful but let's face it, it's going to happen... but what happens when an autonomous vehicle runs over somebody's kid? Who is liable for that? You as the owner of the car? You as the passenger of the car? The manufacturer of the car? The author of the software? The victim (just your bad luck)? I don't ask this just to make a point. I ask because it seems like this question has to be answered before these things can be on the road, and surely it has been. I can't imagine the backers of Waymo putting their money behind this thing (or anyone insuring it) without knowing exactly where their liabilities begin and not, not just waiting to test it in court when the inevitable (and highly unfortunate) finally happens.

Don't get me wrong-- I'm a HUGE fan of this technology. I'm a software engineer, and I'm fascinated by it on a technical level. But I'm also legally blind and cannot drive. In our modern society, that's akin to a prison sentence. I'm largely a prisoner in my home, without relying on others to ferry me around. Yes, there is Uber (and of course my wife) but neither is anything remotely resembling the sense of independence that most people experience. For me and others like me, this would literally revolutionize our access to the world, as for decades we're a small and under-represented population who has never really received any practical solution to this challenge. Autonomous vehicles would close that gap.

I cringe a lot when watching Tesla FSD beta videos, re its wild inconsistency re such safety issues thus far. 

Sometimes it's more timid than proverbial little old lady drivers around pedestrians.  Other times it will blast by big trucks parked on the side of the road with flashers on in a busy residential area, acting completely oblivious that the driver or a random pedestrian might step out from behind the truck. 

It's clearly FAR easier to do what Waymo is doing, one city at a time -- but UNTIL Tesla can PROVE it has a highly reliable generalized solution, the city by city approach outfits like Waymo and Mobileye are taking is clearly superior, re real world geofenced L4 robotaxis being a practical economic model. 

As a person in his 60's, I'm STRONGLY rooting for such robo-taxis becoming common enough and cheap enough that for medical procedures, when my car needs to be worked on, etc, I can easily and affordably take such a cab if walking isn't convenient re distance, weather, how I feel that day, etc.

In the area you are testing, the infrastructure, signs and markings are well maintained.  Better than average.  In Miami and Ft. Lauderdale where I live, such is not the case.  Traffic lines are faded or missing altogether.  Signs are missing, blocked by limbs, faded or missing.  People stop their cars and block lanes meaning the approaching vehicle must come to a sudden stop or swerve around, hoping no one is coming from the other direction.  This, unfortunately is the norm.  There is the reason Waymo uses Phoenix for its testing ground.  This would not work anywhere else.  And there is one more thought to ponder.  Many people, such as myself, enjoy driving.  We don‚Äôt want a computer or another human in the driver seat.  We want the exhilarating feeling of being behind the wheel.  King of the road.

I totally agree that cars should go fully autonomous. Even better, we humans should not even be allowed to drive cars, we are dangerous.

As for Waymo, no, it is not fully autonomous it can't even be considered level 4, it can't think for itself, and it certainly can't predict what others may do. 
Also, it only works on geofenced pre-maped locations that act as "invisible rails" because the car can't understand what is happening around it, it will need machine learning A.I. to do that, while Waymo uses mostly human-writen code.
I could put a few cameras on a car and hard-code it to work around my neighborhood without a driver, this would not make it a fully autonomous car (meaning level 5). This is exactly what Waymo does but on a larger scale because of budget.

Waymo is 6-8 years behind Tesla and will probably never have anything better than lvl 3 that will work out of the specified locations as long as they keep using Lidar and not a vision-only/focused approach with machine learning and a huge amount of data (which they lack) to train it. 

Tesla will have level 5 by the end of 2023 and it will work everywhere, while Waymo will continue to only work on few pre-maped locations. The most important reason for this colossal lead is their approach (vision-based vs lidar), and the second reason is the amount and quality of the data. 
Waymo's number and quality are a joke, Tesla has more than 3.5 BILLION miles (at least 100 times of what Waymo has) on its A.I. and they also have more "real-world" conditions because they are not in few specified locations that are easy to drive around.

While I agree in concept to driverless cars, that they can open a new world to many and potentially save lives, there are still many significant barriers. One is weather - it's not by chance that Waymo is testing in Phoenix Arizona where they typically have 299 sunny days per year.

I think a lot of the stuff in this video focuses on "feeling" confident - it's human to be unconfident. A trained algorithm does everything deterministically - it's go/no go. Probably explains why the car came to a screeching halt on seeing the pedestrian. It also seems like the car might "see" things far away but doesn't react to them. If I see a car moving towards an intersection, even if I know there's a 99.999% chance of it stopping at a red light, I would still take my foot off the accelerator and prepare to stop or make an evasive manoeuvre if it ran the light. Maybe the waymo algorithm is weighted by probabilities of things happening, and not weighted by consequence-weighted probabilities of things happening. As a motorcycle rider, I decide how much room to leave a car based on how attentive the driver of the car seems to be. I make eye contact with the driver before overtaking. Even though the rules say I need x metres of distance at y speed, I will leave more when I have room on the road to do so. With an autonomous system, I have no way of knowing if a car has "seen" me, or is misinterpreting my actions.

Yes, I believe the Waymo cars do exactly that- they look at how much cars wander around (and beyond) their lane and presume that car has a higher variability of movement and account for it i.e. they behave more cautiously. I don't *think* they look inside cars to see if the driver is distracted, but I have a vague sense that with cyclists and pedestrians they do identify which way the human is looking and include that in their predictions about likely future paths.

One of the big differences I see is that the Waymo cars are *patient*. If they think a car is likely to wander into their lane, they'll just keep holding back until it's safe to pass. As a human, I will eventually get grumpy and accelerate past while glaring at the driver.

I completely disagree. I am not a fan of driverless cars:

1. Benefit for a very small array of very big companies.
Developing driverless cars is a technical and most of all a remakable IT challenge.
Only a small group of very big companies are going for it, we see that the challenge is so great that even some already big companies team up for this development.
The manpower and burnt funds for the development are massive.
The very few companies coming through with a safe driverless solution expect of course accordingly extraordinary profilts and return on their investment.

2. Who will be able to use a driverless car in the forseeable future? 
Driverless cars will, given a successful development, operate in areas with high population density and clients who are prepared to pay the extra buck for this.
The vast majority of the polulation in a few "rich" countries won't be able to use driverless cars, not to mention the rest of the world.

3. Who is losing out?
Basically there is no difference between a Uber car , a taxi, or a driverless car. You book the lift,  pick up , and something brings you to a certain destination.
But the driver job feeds a lot of people, as a full time or part time driver. These guys work hard and pay taxes (as we know that this is not so certain for the biggest companies). 
The dream of the driverless car developers is of course to replace all other individual transport services.
In polarized societies it is already difficult for "less qualified" people to find work, this is the wrong direction! No society needs more unskilled workers. 
Another burden for taxpayers? Or more people on the streets?

4. Reasonable investment for future generations?
In times of increasing extreme climate events, droughts, other man-made desasters, still huge areas without proper education,  and many more problems, 
it would have been wiser to use the billions of dollars already burnt for driverless car development for education, environment and sustainable energy research and deployment instead.

Only the tech hype "cool what this can!" does not justify mindless wase of money in gigantic proportions for show, shareholder value, and some possible benefits for a small group of "cool" people in "cool" places.

I undersatand that it is important for professional YouTube content producers to monetize their work. 
This video is but such a cheap, biased and unreflected work and does not fit to the often mentioned high journalistic standards of this channel.
Needed some cash? No problem, mate, Waymo lines your pockets.

What this video does not make clear and I know first hand as a 13-year resident of Chandler Arizona, is that these vehicles are operating in an exceptionally limited context. The eastern boundary of the service area along McQueen road has not moved in years. For all the miles they claim logged, they are covering the same roads over and over, using a substantial sensor array. In all that time, I have not seen a single van run around without a driver. This video is the very first instance and I have spent substantial time near the Waymo depot in addition to watching them drive around my city for years.

On the other hand, I've rented a Tesla model S with FSD beta enabled for an entire week and used that to drive around the northern Virginia area. I was more attentive in the waymo vehicle because I knew I had zero ability to get involved aside from asking the vehicle to stop where the Tesla actually allowed me to relax a bit more with the knowledge I still could take over if I had the need. Considering the costs I've seen so far, waymo would make no sense unless you were writing it infrequently and unless their team pulls out the secret weapon I would pull out (George and Elon were both right and yet missed the bigger picture), it's hard to imagine Waymo being able to provide service over enough area to ever be relevant, especially when compared to what Tesla is already capable of doing with their continuously growing fleet of vehicles, all around the world.

I'll be frank, I am on board with replacing human drivers as soon as possible and this video was a ding to my confidence in that future. We cannot move forward with this technology if "ignore the edge cases, those are rare" is the mindset of the people in charge of it. I sincerely hope that is you injecting your viewpoint onto it and that's not coming from Waymo.

The clip you showed of someone arguing an edge case where it encourages people not to wear helmets is not invalidated by its rareness. People don't act based on statistics. If they did, we wouldn't be in the mess we're in right now in 2021. We don't need to stop pushing autonomous vehicles forward for this helmet question (the system is nowhere near capable enough of accurately identifying safety equipment and making decisions based on it so it's not a relevant question) but other questions DO need to be addressed.

Let me give you a perspective that is a bit more worrying to me. Twice in the past few months we've seen a huge swath of the internet go offline for a few hours when a major cloud host went down. First Google, then Amazon. It's been a wakeup call to some that we've overcentralized our online infrastructure, but others are ignoring it...because of course they are. Just last week we had a zero day where all Apache servers (the most common web server software). The concern with automated driving is it potentially creates a very deadly single point of failure. I don't see that happening with Waymo's current fleet as they are largely autonomous and, importantly, nowhere near the most common vehicle on the road. But let's fast forward to when an automated system controlling vehicles is as common as Toyota vehicles. There are three major issues that need to be clearly addressed before many of us will trust allowing them to grow towards that point.
1. Does it stop working if some external service goes offline - GPS, internet, a server in Toyota's basement, whatever. Obviously, given a certain country it's being developed in, it can currently stand to be without internet for a while because American internet, but we can't get ourselves dependent on a transportation technology that stops functioning entirely if an online service goes down. A smartbulb that won't work anymore because the server discontinued is a small inconvenience, but if Ford goes under and shuts off servers their vehicles depend on, that can result in a lot of slow and painful deaths. 
2. Can the fleet be compromised. The talk of cars that communicate with each other sounds great...unless you work in computing. Then it sounds like someone forgot bad people exist. That sort of inter-connectivity is like handing the nuclear codes to anyone who figures out or is told how to send commands to those cars. If someone figured out how to send the command to accelerate over that communications system (which, even if the communications system doesn't convey commands is still possible) then millions could die within hours.
3. Can individual cars be attacked. For a while, many banks and credit card companies were putting wireless chips in cards and insisting it was "safe". Security experts demonstrated a small loop of wire that could fit in someone's pocket, along with a small control device could pull all the needed information off the cards from a distance and reproduce it on demand. Now those chips aren't in most cards anymore. A few manufacturers are desperately claiming theirs are "safe" but few are gullible enough to believe them now. This one is going to have to be demonstrated, not merely assured. Something like letting a few hacker conventions have at the vehicle on a closed course where they won't have any qualms about making it do things that would otherwise be lethal. This one is more for avoiding unnecessary roadblocks. We don't want car manufacturers to get gunshy about automated software like banks did with the card chips. Yes, you can get people to quickly trust the car to drive, but it can just as quickly generate distrust and outrage if one person gets killed because a malicious individual tricked the vehicle into doing something wrong. You would also need to test against large scale shutdown attacks such as saturating an area with the right frequency of light that the LIDAR is using or painting something with a material that scatters or absorbs that light.

Saving lives is a good goal, but if you leave the door open to losing more lives, or if you rush forward so fast that you stumble and slow down the process, then you've done a disservice. Being better than what we have now isn't good enough. We have to work through the ramifications of it to avoid unintended consequences.

Many years ago, people worked out that putting lead in gasoline would solve a major problem. And an entire generation got lead poisoning from that. Unintended consequences can be disastrous beyond your wildest dreams, especially for something as ubiquitous as transportation. We need this technology to succeed, not be held back by early failures that could have been anticipated if we had listened to the people we thought were just naysayers.
You led Waymo, and it MATTERS!

There are SO many things wrong with the content here (and with Derek's logic).  
Equating "driverless elevators" with driverless cars is ridiculous (and the bogus claim that "there was one guy who was like 'I don't care if I have to walk up 12 flights of stairs for the rest of my life; I'm not taking that elevator'" is just laughably weak.  "Yes, don't be like that crazy guy, folks!").  What were the potential risks of riding in an elevator without an operator?  (1) falling to your death, (2) being crushed by doors that don't close while it's in motion, or (3) ending up on the wrong floor.  Are ANY of those as likely as a driverless car going 70 mph colliding with a car that's merging into your lane?  NOPE.  Making elevators immune from the 3 risks listed took electromechanical engineers of the 1920s a couple of years.  That's it.  It wasn't until WWII when elevator operators (who had frequently gone on strike to protect their jobs from being eliminated by automation) were finally dispensed with as unnecessary.  

Comparing them with airline autopilots is likewise nonsensical.  Autopilots (or "flight management systems") use things that driverless cars cannot, such as the fact that every commercial aircraft has a flight-plan that is filed ahead of time, so they can be networked to avoid collision.  No such thing will happen with driverless cars.  When an aircraft is in flight, other than during takeoff or landing, the main dangers to avoid are terrain (when in doubt, gain altitude), and bad weather (weather systems are _large_ and avoiding them is hardly brain surgery).  This is _nothing_ like the constantly evolving, real-time dangers that self-driving cars *that must move in very tightly-defined vehicle lanes* must contend with, from unpredictable drivers, cyclists, pedestrians, animals (wile and domestic), obstacles like blown-over signs, lost loads, stray wheels, garbage, sand, etc., that plague roadways.  So Waymo (and Derek) are presenting an _utterly false equivalency_ with autopilots.

As with EVERY new technology, driverless cars are being oversold on best-case scenarios, and worst-case scenarios are being swept under the rug.  Remember how computers were going to be "foolproof" electronic brains?  Remind me how that worked out.  Within a few years of the proliferation of the networked PC, everything from viruses to coronal mass ejections were wreaking havoc.  Has your cell phone EVER failed?  Of course it has.  In most cases, it's just an inconvenience (albeit a frustrating one).  Do you actually believe that self-driving cars or the networks that connect them will be immune to things like glitches, hacks, system failures, bad patches, exploits, malware, "blue screens of death", etc.?  If so, you haven't been paying attention to the past 25 years of high-tech reality.  Any one of those things could cripple a self-driving car, cause it to crash, or cause an entire network to go down, bringing thousands of self-driving cars to a standstill.  They will *also* become very attractive targets for ransomware and cyberattacks.

To all of you why are saying that video sponsorships are ethically fine, because after all, Derek needs an income to live, consider this: this one video earned Derek about $10,000 just from Google AdSense (and who knows how much more Waymo paid him).  A YT content creator with 11 million subscribers, like Derek has, producing just 2 videos a month, will be bringing in about $250,000 per year.  One video per week: double that.  
Yes, there is overhead to consider (equipment, help, travel, etc.) but Derek is in no danger of going broke if he *doesn't* accept corporate sponsorship.  Videos like this just damage a creator's credibility, and may lose them subscribers.

1:37 One of such places is Moscow. Roads are sometimes meh, weather is quite difficult for LIDARs and cameras, traffic is heavy and fast and drivers are... Well, let's say I felt way more comfortable riding a *self-driving* taxi than some of the normal ones. Maybe Yandex Self-Driving Cars are doing so well specifically thanks to the challenge, developers have to act smart and quite paranoid. Once I saw a video of a Waymo car stopping because it started raining a bit, and was like "Wut?", because in Moscow you might as well not bother leaving the garage if you can't handle such weather.
Note that I worked at Yandex Self-Driving Group (a year ago) and participated in developing those cars, and even knowing how "raw" the technology was on the inside didn't scare me. Yes, it might take closer to a decade to surpass a "professional driver in an ideal state of mind and health", but I'd guess the autopilot already is safer than most taxi drivers. It has reaction time so short that humans can't even dream of getting close, and can "see" so much more with its sensors than two eyes and a couple mirrors could possibly allow. And if it fails, it is far more likely to just stop, maybe cause a traffic jam until a human intervenes, and that's it.
As far as I know, the only road accidents involving Yandex cars were pretty much them stopping at the traffic lights and getting hit from behind by some texting-at-the-wheel idiot who failed to stop.

A driverless car would be ideal for my visually impaired girlfriend as it would solve her problem of short distance to medium distance travel. A lot of her time is wasted going to the start point of public transport, switching public transport and from end point to final destination. However, this technology is only viable if it's truly autonomous 100% of the time. That means not only must it be able to navigate all kinds of obstacles like roadworks and accidents, but also all kinds of weather. (Rain still seems to be a problem for Waymo sensory systems.) A lot of road infrastructure has to be either changed or augmented to accommodate these vehicles. For example traffic regulatory systems (traffic lights, speed signs, etc) need some way of communicating with the vehicle as well as communication between vehicles. Also for better or worse a lot of legislation has to be done. (It took literally centuries to come up with road rules.) And we as a society have to accept that small and major accidents will happen. I also imagine that "car ownership" is going to be an issue. It looks that Tesla bets that cars will be still owned by the majority of individuals, while the rest (Alphabet, Ford, etc) assumes that a "car as a service" is the more likely outcome. I can imagine that we might not even have individual cars in the future, but something that is a hybrid between car, bus and train.
So from an engineering point of view I understand your enthusiasm. In the end it's not the engineering but timing and luck which determines the success of autonomous vehicles.

Nothing against Veritasium, but I've never been a huge fan of his videos. I'm just here because I saw that video by Tom and I wanted to see what the fuss was about. Frankly, I'm underwhelmed. I don't see anything to be outraged about. On several points I feel like Tom's critique was unfair. Even little stuff like Derek's "shrug" after saying "full disclosure...". There was no shrug. The look on his face was at best ambiguous. It didn't read to me as dismissive. I really hate little jabs like that because you feel petty/nitpicky in correcting them but they aren't accurate. Or where Tom critiques Derek's "spinning" the vehicle stopping for a pedestrian as a good thing. I didn't notice any "spinning", I don't see a problem with his discussion of it at all.

  But on more substantive parts I also find lacking. One of the central complaints Tom has is that Derek never addresses that Waymo only works in Phoenix. But he does address it, at 1:36. The critique about omission, to me, was the most egregious. This is a central problem of creating a short "edutainment" video. You have to omit a ton. It's an 18 minute video. Of course Derek didn't go into an explanation of deep learning and training algorithms and whatever else. It's supposed to be an entertaining video. It's also never been the style of the channel (at least as best I remember) to give a nuanced view. It's always a very upbeat fun video about the positives or interesting part of some sciency topic. His target audience really has always felt to me to be very broad. That's part of why he's not really my cup of tea. I personally like getting into the nitty gritty and the nuance and exploring the various sides of these subjects. But that's not really what he does. It more feels like he's trying to inspire interest and leave you with a positive or even hopeful feeling.

 And on the point of omission, I felt like Tom's dismissal of the airplane and elevator arguments was somewhat comical. Elevators don't count because they travel on only one dimension. And airplanes don't count because.. Hang on, airplanes are three dimensions, shouldn't they count extra or something!? Why did Tom omit that? Isn't that "misinformation by omission"? Are dimensions really that important to Tom, or was it just a convenient way to dismiss a point? One could imagine the argument in reverse, "sure we automated cars, they are only in two dimensions no way we could automate airplanes, they are in three dimensions!" I do agree that cars are the harder problem, but that's why they are being solved last. We are making use of much more complex technology to solve it. Elevators required very little and were automated around 1900, planes required more the first commercial planes with autoland entered service in the early 1960s, and cars require a dizzying amount and for last 15 years or so have felt 5 years off. 

This is not to say I found all of Derek's arguments convincing. For example, parking vehicles less won't necessarily decrease the total numbers of cars produced. If we park a vehicle half as often, it actually needs to drive significantly more, because it needs to drive empty between people during the downtime. Total miles increases, and vehicles have lives measured in miles. If everything else is equal, total number of cars required in a country per year goes up not down. You have other issues as well, experts predict usage would go way up without the need for drivers, which would also need more (just imagine if you could just go to sleep and wake up in the morning at the Grand Canyon, imagine how many road trips you'd go on). A lot of autonomous cars are all electric cars, and they tend to last longer than gasoline engines, which would mean less cars produced. Less wrecks would would mean less cars produced. In net total I'm not sure. I don't think this is an example of bias from advertisement though. I think it's just an example of surface level analysis that comes with an entertaining YouTube video. 

  For what it's worth I don't really like advertisement in general, but especially when there is a potential conflict of interest, and doubly so when it's native advertising. But I just don't really see any evidence that Veritasium handled it irresponsibly.

Honestly the Waymo sponsorship didn't sour my opinion of you. The Head & Shoulders ad didn't sour my opinion of you. Tom Nicholas' video didn't sour my opinion of you.

Your response to Tom Nicholas absolutely soured my opinion of you. It's amazing how quickly trust can be destroyed. I've been watching this channel for close to a decade now. The way you chastised him for legitimate criticism and kept coming back to get your ass handed to you in the comments is the demeanor of a petulant child, not a respected professional. It was far, far worse than Johnny Harris' response, which was already not very good. 

I hope you take his criticism to heart and stop posting this misleading corporate advertising. This is not the way you make the "world's best science documentaries", or whatever that long-forgotten goal was, I can't seem to remember anymore.

It's not too hard to imagine some bad scenarios: maybe Waymo could require you to log in with your Google account before the car goes anywhere (think of all the data they could mine from you); or maybe if Google knows your search history and doesn't like you, it'll pick and choose who will get into a car accident that day. Furthermore there is the general issue that your safety is also at risk if the car gets hacked or gets malware installed on it. You mentioned that the car stops for sirens, but there have been incidents where criminals pretend to be police officers and pull people over to rob them; would it stop for a fake siren too? What happens if it tries to cross a mountain road covered in ice and snow, or it tries to drive in a crowded area like New York City? I'm not convinced just by watching it take a leisurely stroll around a calm neighborhood that it can handle all the complex situations that drivers find themselves in. And I'm not convinced that we should be giving up our security and privacy just for a little bit of convenience.

It is a very interesting topic. Let me clear something out first. I am fully onboard for autonomous cars. What trips me a bit (and probably people who are trying to find evidence against autonomous cars) is all these claims of 20 million miles. How much more experience this is compared to a regular driver. Objectively speaking this is true. But on the other hand, you Derek said it yourself - this car will probably struggle on poorly maintained roads for example. And yet, myself a driver with only 130 000 km of experience (basically a rookie compared to this car) have no problem whatsoever driving on poorly maintained road or on a dirt road.

I am software engineer and I have tried to explain the benefits of self driving cars to people and I see a very common set of misconceptions.
What people seem to struggle to understand is that computer algorithm driving a car will be MUCH better than a human in 99% of the situations. The problem is that in the remaining 1%, due to their nature, computers tend to make mistakes that seem so obvious for us humans that we apply our confirmation bias and shot down the idea.

The thing is, as you said 99% of mistakes are basically not obeying the traffic laws or getting intentionnaly or unintentionally distracted. A computer will never do that. The thing is us humans alwasy think "yeah, that will never happen to me, so I dont see the benefit for myself!". The computer being a giant calculator looking for patterns might (in 1 in a million) find a pattern where there shouldn't be and execute a maneuver that may result in an accident. This is what we see with Tesla and with virtually any other brand at some point. The car driving seemingly perfect and  just make a turn and leave the road or simply ignore a stopped vehicle and cause an accident. This is the nature of algorithms. Poorly programmed or trained model could make such a mistake. Of course a human would react like "WTF the car just made a right turn on the highway and got out of the road, a human would never make such a stupid mistake!".

Of course such a mistake would be against (probably 100 000 mistakes on the human side) making it so extremely rare that statistically it is not even worth discussing.

My point with this long comment is that sometimes in their attempt to promote their progress, companies like Waymo make a big bold statement like "we have 20 million miles of experience, much more than a human" that they provoke a reaction like "Oh yeah, 20 million miles, huh? I drove for 20 000 and I can drive on a poorly mainteined road and you cant!"

Maybe a bit more transparancy on what those numbers mean in reality and a bit more education on how things work and why they are better even though they seemingly sometimes make not the best judgements from the perspective of a human driver might push things in the right direction. A quick example is the quck sudden squeeking stop infront of the man with the cart. This kind of a stop is to be expected from a very rookie driver and even though I fully understand why such things happen, people will tend not to expect such "attitude" from someone or something that has droven 20 million miles.

Passenger cars traveled 1.2 trillion miles in the US in 2018. There were about 5 million accidents, with 4 million on good weather (when autonomous vehicles operate today). Assuming all of them happened with passenger cars, we have roughly 300,000 miles driven/accident. Waymo in the latest autonomy test in California reported about 30,000 miles/disengagement- where disengagement means the human teleoperator  had to intervene to avoid an accident. Can current technology alone improve this 10x? Even then it would just match humans. Sensor resolutions in silicon are still not matching the human apparatus. Self driving is going to be a better cruise control for a while. In fact properly designed advanced cruise control has been shown to reduce accident rates in highways. Lots of money are being thrown at self driving but we still need sensing technology breakthroughs. Most likely a next gen chip for image sensing that matches human eye resolution and light capture. Beware of the hype surrounding these companies.

Every driverless car on the road makes the road safer for everyone.  The errors made by autonomous vehicle are so rare that they make headlines, even though human drivers make mistakes just as deadly and far more frequently per mile driven.

There's one huge unsolved problem though, and it's not a technical issue.

When a driverless car makes a mistake, who pays for it?

Our entire accountability infrastructure is built around the assumption that the driver is responsible for everything the car does.  If you take the driver out of the equation, our fundamental assumptions about liability fall to pieces.  Waymo gets around this by having every step in the chain from engineering to practice in the hands of a single entity.  If Derek had been in an accident, Waymo's insurance would have covered any liability.

To own autonomous vehicles privately, we must first rewrite the entire legal foundation of auto insurance.

I am less concerned with the technology. I am more concerned about the liability and the human factor. If a train or a plane crashes, killing people on board, the company operating those vehicles is (or should be) held liable for damages. For human factor concerns, consider that when you are a passenger in a car, you take some mental comfort in knowing the driver is putting himself at risk in the car with you, so there is some shared comfort in knowing that (most of the time) the risk is shared equally by both the operator of the vehicle and the passenger. A similar situation presents itself in military situations - ground troops have expressed that they prefer manned air support over unmanned air support due to the fact they take some comfort knowing someone else is also risking their life with them in the situation, rather than some drone pilot halfway around the earth - drones are quite soulless and that is not reassuring when you are on the ground under fire. Regarding personal driverless vehicles and driverless taxi services like Waymo, I'll feel more confident when laws regarding liability are explicitly more robust than they currently are. Nothing against the technology, and I have no issues with the statistical evidence driving the march toward driverless vehicles - computers are more reliable, statistically. I prefer to pilot my own vehicle responsibly, but having the choice is a freedom we should all be able to have as long as the legal/liability/responsibility issues are well defined before a large system goes online.

20 million miles means virtually nothing when many of them occurred in Chandler which has wide, straight roads. Low traffic density. Virtually no pedestrians or animals, and sunny clear weather 350 days a year. Also, many of those miles took place in 2020 when nobody was on the road anyway. This is as close to controlled "lab conditions" as one can get, albeit still forcing the general public to participate in a technology experiment without their consent (Nuremburg has some words on that). Throw in dense traffic, high pedestrian density, snow, fog, deer, roads designed for horses with blind turns, etc and we've trained cars to self drive in the least common driving scenarios found on the planet.

I like how he talks about airplane autopilot like it's a guarantee safety feature and TOTALLY ignores Boeing and the 737 Max crashes that killed hundreds because the technology was not thoroughly tested before being deployed. This is a major problem with autonomous vehicles as a whole, a bug in the code is one thing on your smartphone, it's a wholly separate issue when it turns a two ton piece of machinery into an eradict and potentially lethal projection. It's one thing when there's a "bug" in a human but that human can be held accountable and is only responsible for their individual vehicle, it's a huge problem when that bug is instantly propogated across millions of vehicles and can't be overriden by the drivers (or they aren't expecting to need to override the systems...a stark contrast from pilots that are highly trained and paid to always be attentive). That's not even to address the cybersecurity issue, and we all know how great silicon valley is about cybersecurity.

Computers are great at being consistent, but the road is anything but consistent. Even without drivers there are too many variables from construction, to debris, to weather, to pedestrians that make the road chaotic. The sky is comparably far less complex as there's air traffic control, radar, a whole third dimension to maneuver in, and less objects to collide with as a whole. Humans on the other hand are terrible at being consistent, but fantastic at handling novel situations. That's not to say that self driving cars are a fool's errand, it's just to say that the technology is not ready for public roads and never should have been allowed (the algorithms don't even have to pass a driver's test like a 15 year old kid has too). Even experts in the industry are coming out and saying the technology is farther away than anticipated, many saying at least a decade away. Remember, we were supposed to have self driving cars by 2020 when the tech was first being hyped, and it's still in it's infancy with only one company having road trials (in the most lax regulatory state with the easiest road conditions). Even then, the cars drive erratically and get into collisions, where WAYMO refuses to disclose any contextual information about the events, and I've personally seen them constantly driving bike lanes. It seems like self driving cars might go the way of flying cars and cold fusion, a decade away, every decade.

Another issue is that they're comparing safety to the average american driver, which is a poor standard as we can pretty easily surmise that self driving cars will be replacing commercial and luxury vehicles first, two demographics that statistically are the safest drivers with millions of miles between collisions. In other words, the algorithms need to be far safer than the average driver to not LOWER average road safety in the adoption phase (these are things actuaries are already concerned about and they don't care about hype or promises, just raw data and risk).

Lastly, this all ignores a huge elephant in the room: cities designed around private individual cars, whether autonomous and electric or not, is a poor design model. Changing who and how a car drives does nothing to address the well studied problems that cities based on individual driving ALWAYS suffer more traffic, more pollution, more urban sprawl, more heat island, and more climate change problems. Technology, whether wider roads, or safer and faster cars, has never realized the promises made to sell the technology. The only things that do alleviate the problems of urban and suburban traffic are increased public mass transportation, and actively discouraging individual drivers. Imagine how bad the roads are going to be when all these autonomous vehicles are not kept in the garage but rather "rented" out with some kind of driverless Lyft service. Cars on the road could easily double as they all idle waiting for a fare, rather than sitting parked. Oh yeah, work from home is a far easier, cheaper, and faster to implement way to address the dangers of road, but it doesn't create a bunch of BS jobs to make a fundamentally flawed system appear less flawed without dramatically fixing anything (seat belts, crumple zones, and assisted driving/braking have already addressed the vast majority of the dangers of driving anyway).


I want autonomous vehicles, I'd love to not have to pay attention on road trips and not have to fly nearly as much. I'm pro the technology, but just because I'm for something doesn't mean the technology is anywhere near ready and should be "generally regarded as safe" just because we want it. That's the same logic that created Thalidomide or Theranos or so many failed kickstarters. Hype isn't the same as reality and technologists need to stop treating potentially lethal technology as a benign advancement with no risks.

Well, I never expected anything as misleading as this puff-piece from Veritasium.

Aircraft? You can't compare those to cars. Of course aircraft are much safer when flown using automatic systems because they are complex things and not driving down 2D roads. But on autoland, the plane just flies down a glide path that's been cleared by air traffic control and is illuminated by a radio beacon, and that's a much simpler thing to do than driving a car through a busy city in a rainstorm. So simple in fact that the basic system was developed over 80 years ago.

Oh, and talking about rainstorms, could it be just a coincidence that Waymo only operates in one of the driest places in the US? Currently, they can only function in "light rain" because Lidar just doesn't like rain. Rain appears as noise in the reflected image and greatly reduces the system's range and accuracy. A really good AI might be able to compensate for this, so let me know when Waymo have driven 20 million miles down freeways in torrential rain and I might be less dismissive.

And you can pooh-pooh trolley problems all you like, but they do exist in real life. Say a deer runs out in front of me on a fast, busy road. If the system brakes hard, the car behind might run into me, but if it doesn't brake, the deer might come through the windshield and kill me. I'm NOT saying that I could make a better decision, for all I know, the Waymo system might estimate the mass of the deer and compare the kinetic energy of the collision to the deformation strength of the bodywork and so on, but ultimately it will have to make the decision, and it's a potentially life-or-death one.

I heard several experts (including Elon Musk) say that Lidar is a technological dead end and so is every autonomous car system that relies on it.
It is way too expensive, too energy consuming, too maintenance requiring and too prone to failure because of all the moving parts. It works on small fleets of test vehicles that don't have to be economically viable, but it would not work on a large scale.
And most importantly, it doesn't work in rain or any other adverse weather conditions. Even heavy smog and dust can incapacitate it.

Those Waymo cars literally can only work under the weirdly ideal Californian weather conditions and are totally useless anywhere else, so it is really questionable what those people think they are doing.

Imagine a future where people don't have cars anymore and rely on ordering autonomous cars based on Lidar technology in California and then you have one of those raging bush fires and nobody can evacuate anymore because the cars can't drive in smoky conditions.

So my only issue with driverless cars is the 'car as a service' thing. It's the same issue I have with Uber (and taxis in general). I didn't learn to drive until I was 36 years old as I'd always lived in a city and just never felt the need, taxis and public transport was abundant and easy. Then I moved to a rural area when I was 32, for years I had to put up with not being able to get an Uber, to having to wait an hour for a bus or a train (if it didn't get cancelled, which it frequently did) and struggling to get a taxi. So I learned to drive and bought a car and it completely changed my life.

Now, if self-driving cars come out soon then I'll be getting one the moment I can afford it, I'd love one BUT I probably wouldn't be interested in services like Waymo - at least not until they are ubiquitous - as you just know that the rural areas won't be getting the same level of service as the cities for a LONG time. I highly doubt that we will eliminate personal ownership of vehicles - self-driving or otherwise - for at least 30-40 years. Right now, I can jump in my car, go to the supermarket, do a shop and be home within 30 mins (15 if it is just a quick pop in and out) - before driving I had to set aside 2 hours for that same trip and even though that was giving myself extra time for taxi/bus troubles, it actually took that long (or even occasionally longer) far too often. Cars as a service will have to be a LOT better before I'd give up having my own car.

Spectacularly light on the actual challenges. This isn't a technical problem to solve, that's been done already - autonomous vehicles have been operating inside closed systems for decades. The problems aren't technical. The problems are social and legal. The reason all those questions about "who does the car hit, this guy or this guy?" weren't about how to prepare for those situations, but were about learning what a "reasonable" person would do... why? Because that's what a jury convicts on. If the car took a "reasonable" action, the execs can't be held accountable if they've got the data to prove that it did what a normal, ordinary, "reasonable" person would do.

Waymo's business model is that of a cab company or a ridesharing app (somewhat less alike) in these business model what is sold to the end user is not a vehicle or an autonomous system. The sales unit is transportation from point A to point B. This immediately shifts all legal responsibility  to the service provider. In the same way that if you get into a cab and it crashes, the driver of said cab along with the company that owns said cab service will deal with the legal repercussions. Not the customer in the back of the cab.  This is why autonomous driving works so well on this specific business model. Not only is the legal responsibility clearly defined, but it is massively profitable for the service provider (since they save on the salary of drivers and gets much lower accident rates) , is a win - win all around if and when you have both: autonomous driving & is sold as a service. I used to drive a taxi, I had an accident because someone stuck in an intersection could not see the light, or on coming traffic and proceeded cause an almost head on accident. That and I was also involved in two rear end collisions both where my vehicle was stopped. The first at a traffic light, the guy behind me thought the light in his lane changed because cars in the left turn lane started moving. The other was when traffic came to a stand still on the freeway and the next car struck me at close 55mph. I personally was to blame for the three additional accidents during my 17 years as a taxi driver. I calculate that during that time I drove over 2,386,800 miles. I used the average of 5 days a week although I often worked 6-7 days a week for most of those years. I often worked 12-16 hours, I even have worked 3 days straight, napping between trips. The naps allowed me to get enough sleep that I did not need quit working to as much 17-18 hours per day. That being said 6 possibly 7 accidents (in case I forgot one) in 17 years years prove I am above average. I however know a more amazing driver that I aspired to be like, my own father. He drove from his home to work and back from his job to home every day for more than 20 years, roughly 22-23 years, and still transported his family to shopping and other places as fathers often do. A trip to work for him was 62 miles, sometimes more, because in the summer he would take a 10-12 mile detour on his way to work to drop me, my brother or sister to grandma's house on his way to work, or pick us up on the way home. He was involved in accidents, but all of the were the OTHER persons fault. He had zero accidents to his name in over 20+ years. I miss my old man, but I still aspire to drive as good as him. There were man times I watched in amazement as an eminent accident was avoided by him pulling some crazy maneuver that somehow slipped us through a gap, around a swerving vehicle and avoiding a seemingly avoidable accident. The man had skills. Waymo sounds like it has my dads driving skills!!!

@@TheSHARCRASH Tesla is at Level 4 in production cars, and has been for quite some time. There is however legal limitations to level 4 in all countries, except for a few projects such as the Waymo.

Even my 4 year old Hyundai is at level 2. 

Now, that really has no bearing on your original question. The question of AP usage in crashes has come up numerous times, and while the legalities might become challenging at Level 5, which is rather limited if you still need to have a legally responsible human designated for each trip. (Certified, sober, awake, probably seated in the left front seat), there are lots of lots of interesting cases from the aviation world of where the responsibility crosses over from the Pilot in command (airline representative) to the manufacturer or the designer of the automated system involved in an accident. 

The question about data integrity likewise has come up both in the aircraft-world (Famously as early as Air France 296) but also with Tesla having had more than a few drivers blame their auto pilot when their right foot got too heavy, or when they opted to comment on you tube videos rather than watching the road, even when accepting full legal responisibility when enabling auto pilot. The integrity of the data itself has never really been put into question when reviewed by courts. It is not the easiest ¬´document fraud¬ª out there. 

It would be very hard to manipulate data in a way that wouldn‚Äôt contradict evidence pulled from other potential sources such as dash cams, witnesses, surveillance cams, the damages to the car and other vehicles, there are also inter-car comunication being developed, (ITS/Vanet/IVC type V2V-solutions)so within few years, the car would have comunicated quite a lot of data about its status to nearby vehicles that can be pulled and used as evidence. It would potentially damage the manufacturer in to oblivion if caught only once tampering with such data. 

Easier to make a good autonomous system in the first place.

I disagree that autonomous fleets in cities are going to come before autonomous cars in smaller areas. Or, at least, I _hope_ that won't happen. As you briefly glossed over towards the end, most accidents with autonomous vehicles are going to happen because other drivers mess up, and cities are precisely where there are going to be the largest concentration of potentially error-prone human drivers. An ideal situation from a safety standpoint is actually the fully-autonomous vehicles becoming more common in suburbs and slowly moving into the cities. Kudos to Waymo for the intensive testing and realizing that half-measures won't work with our stupid ape brains, though; I'm remembering Tesla putting cars on the road that _did_ , in fact, hit stationary objects, and people doing ridiculous things (even filming a porn!) in their partially-autonomous vehicles. Anyway, hopefully they're right that autonomous vehicles reduce fatalities even in the face of human error, because, to touch on your analogies, that's the _real_ reason pilots are required to be in the cockpit during takeoff and landing. Fog isn't much of an obstacle to a computer with a perfect map of the runway system and knowledge of its own x,y,z coordinates, velocity, and acceleration; however, another aircraft with no autopilot or a sudden malfunction can cause collisions without a pilot to end the landing program and move out of the way. (That's also why the elevator analogy isn't a very good one: The most complicated part of driving or piloting is maneuvering around other drivers and pilots, which isn't something an elevator operator ever had to worry about.)

You're definitely skipping over the main reason that we won't be above 50% autonomous cars in the next five or even ten years, though: Economics. In ten years, I _might_ be able to afford a ten-year-old human-driven electric car (but probably not). It'll be even longer before I can afford an autonomous car. And I'm only hovering slightly above the poverty line; there's plenty of people well into poverty who need a car to keep food on the table and a roof over their heads; and even people who are safely lower-middle class don't tend to have _new_ cars, just not-quite-as-old used cars. Most people don't have new cars, because new cars are expensive, and new cars with the latest technology features are more expensive still. The average car on the road in the US is a decade old right now (actually, 12.1, but just coming out of lockdown, the economy's still a bit out of whack, bumping the average up a bit; it was hovering in the high 11.x before that), meaning many are even older.

Also, that motorcyclist with/without a helmet scenario isn't a very good one to begin with, and whoever made the video you clipped from also misunderstood the point of such scenarios. It's actually not a question of how well the car will perform, so much as it's a question of legal liability. To demonstrate, have a much better and more realistic example: What happens when someone has been tailgating you, and then the person in front of you stops short? The car is probably capable of stopping short to avoid the car in front, causing it to get rear-ended; and it's capable of recognizing the car behind is too close and fast, thus stopping slowly and hitting the car in front. That _isn't_ an uncommon situation, unfortunately, and it's entirely due to human driver error _by other drivers_ , meaning the autonomous car may not be able to avoid it. (No, you don't get to brush that one off with "unlikely hypothetical scenarios." I have first- and secondhand experience with _exactly_ that scenario at least five times over.) The sticking point is this: Which scenario is safer for the passengers of all three cars, and should the car potentially seek to preserve its own passenger's safety, even at the expense of another vehicle's driver's life? In that scenario, I can easily imagine a situation where hitting the front car would severely injure the passenger (say, by smashing their face into the dashboard), but getting hit by the rear car would kill the driver (maybe they're not wearing a seatbelt). This is all potentially knowable by the autonomous vehicle, so what heuristic is the best one to use when you know you're going to be in court for your programming someday? Once that choice is made, who gets the blame when someone is injured, partially as the result of that decision? The programmer? The manufacturer? The vehicle's owner? The vehicle's passengers, who presumably chose the route that put it on that road? Again, it's a question of liability, one that should probably be figured out now, but one which, given the way our courts run on precedent, probably won't actually be figured out until it actually happens. However, anyone who uses those scenarios to _criticize_ autonomous vehicles has a fundamental misunderstanding of what the problem actually is.

Just to inform those who get kinda mislead by this video. just know that WAYMO IS NOT A FULLY AUTONOMOUS SELFDRIVING CAR WHICH CAN TAKE YOU ANYWHERE. 
Before a waymo car can drive on a road the road first has to be 2d and 3d mapped processed and so on before the car is allowed to drive down that raod. After which the car knows every 10th of an inch of the whole street, this way they dont have to worry about anything else than the other things moving, such as people, cars and so on.

This strategy works quite well in suburbs and probably pretty well in bigger cities as well, but youd have to have a extremely detailed map of the entire earth before being able to take a road trip in it to where ever you want.

This is why this looks 100x better that the tesla and why it has all of these sensors, cause it needs to know where it is correlating to the premapped 3d world it has been given. New roads and so on (road construction especially) is therefor also one of the downsides to this strategy, since the car doesnt know what to do when the enviroment doesnt corelate to is map. 

Tesla is trying to do full autonomy, that in real time maps out its environment and surroundings and actively finds the safest yet quickest route to the destination

Hope it cleared things up :)

I mean just a few of the current problems of waymo:

1. The scalability. You need to complete map out the city and then run rigorous Simulation + test rides before even thinking about deploying the waymo system there (at least with their current fsd approach). So bringing the system to a new city would potentially take years.

2. Cars are getting stuck often. In difficult situation the car often just stops. There is a team of drivers for every 2-3 waymo cars on the streets, which just shows you how unreliable they are at the moment. They then have to drive to the car and take over manually. Obviously this will get better with time but it would take potentially years until you really would Not need any human backup.

3. The crash statistics might be biased. As the other drivers know, that waymo cars are driverless they may watch out more to them as they don't trust the waymo cars and thus be more careful around them

4. Adverserial attacks. Basically hacking the neural nets by giving them weird inputs like a weird picture. Although not a problem yet (as it is quite difficult and highly theoretical at this point) but a potential hacker might print a weird picture on a banner which then basically completely bricks the car/leads to a crash etc.

Just to name a few critical point I wished where in this video. Don't get me wrong it is astonishing, what tech is able to do and waymos approach is currently the most promising. However this video was just absolutely uncritical, basically just reading a script that waymo gave you, which is really sad.

Regulators should absolutely push back on tech giants currently.

This may be a very unimportant thing that I'm about to say, but I think the anxiety we feel when entering one of these autonomous cars at least partially comes from the fact that you're looking at a normal car, with a driver's seat and steering wheel. We see that there is visibly and obviously something missing (a driver) and we naturally get anxious when we feel like something's missing, like when you suddenly get that sinking feeling like you forgot your wallet even when you didn't.

This became apparent to me when you showed footage of you in the firefly. I didn't feel any anxiety at all looking at that interior even though I felt plenty vicariously through the footage of you in the chrysler minivan. The firefly just has a seat for the riders, like a rollercoaster at an amusement park. There's no steering wheel, no driver's seat, no brakes or pedals, and that unconsciously sends a signal to my brain that says "that's how it's supposed to be, we'll be ok". In the waymo vehicle, once you start seeing the steering turning on its own (confidently, in your words), it also activates that same thought process in my mind, the one of reassurance and relief.

I'm amazed by the comments.  Some say  "here's the real problem.. transition". Others say insurance is the problem.  The problem isn't even addressed in the video and Waymo knows the issue.    The problem is the network.   Networks are not safe and can be breached.  Period.  In clear weather the car is fine from a sensor input point of view.  It follows the program rules but it's communicating to a server.   At issue are the software breaches. In 2020, ransomware attacks rose by 700%.  Nothing at a server level is safe and eventually, if these became that popular, which probably won't happen for this very reason, a company could breach the system and control the car; cause it to crash.  It could lock the doors.  It' could threaten you with your life while driving 100mph.  It could threaten the company running the cars off the road unless ransom was paid.  That's the first problem.  The second problem is Americans love to drive. Unfettered. Unwatched and totally free.   The end.  There will be spotty levels of random success.  Other than that it's a no-go.

One important advantage of humans is improvisation. For example, if you see a road worker holding a stop sign, you treat it differently than if you see a stop sign in the ground. They are the same sign but the context makes you treat them differently. A self-driving car would see them as identical if it wasn't specifically programmed to tell the difference. Eventually, infrastructure will be reorganized for self-driving cars, but it is currently tailored for humans.

Also, the Waymo self-driving cars are specifically designed for one city. The only unpredictable aspect is the traffic. They are still very impressive, but the technology is not as close as Waymo makes it seem.

The misrepresentation of planes is astonishing from a science channel. Pilots guided by computers and not at all relying on the computer to take off or land. The showcased air accident was only one example when eventually the computer was used. What about many accidents when the computer took over and created a dangerous situation or fatal accident. Remember those too? Strangely haven't mentioned. I have no doubt computers are good and helpful but humans in fact are better to judge a situation and act accordingly. I cannot avoid the fact that this video was sponsored by Waymo. It certainly shows.

The problem is that it's not a representative test. The reason it's only in Phoenix right now isn't just legal. It's because it has some of the most consistently favorable driving conditions out of anywhere in the country. Generally well maintained mostly suburban roads. Less than a third as many days if rain as the national average, and less than a quarter total rainfall. No snow at all. They don't go downtown, just a few suburbs close by. Which is fortunate, as you neglected to mention the cars don't go on any roads with speed limits over 45 and PULL OVER for heavy rain.

It's one thing to say, that they don't need to be perfect in every situation. It's another entirely to suggest that driving on a tiny fraction of ideal roads in ideal condition signifies that they are anywhere close to ready for prime time.

Now let's talk timeline. Suggesting anything less than 10 years is a complete pipe dream for any reasonable level of adoption, for a very simple reason. The average car on the road today is 11.5 years old (ok, mixing average and median here, but surprisingly median was hard to find), and you still can't buy one! So even if a fully autonomous car hit the road TODAY, and it was the only car anyone ever bought ever again, the majority of cars would still have human drivers ten years from now. +/- some percentage for fleets which will see faster adoption, but over 85 percent of Americans drive themselves or carpool, which means they are going to have to buy one.

But we're still missing yet another problem. Even if waymo vans were able to drive on most roads, which they can't, and drive in adverse conditions, which they can't, and drive at highway speeds, which they don't, and they were for sale, which they aren't, nobody would be able to afford them! The CEO of waymo put the cost if a single van at around 180,000 dollars earlier this year. Now sure, if you happen to be one of the biggest companies in the world, you can make yourself a fleet, but the average person, or even a small cab or rides share company? Forget it.

One has to admit this technology here is being tested in pristine conditions.  Not just in terms of weather and topography, but in terms of auto manufacturers haven't got their squirrely brained fingers on it.  Yet.

Having driven cars since the 70's, with memories of my dad driving cars from the 50's and 60's, I've seen a lot of changes.  And, if I was a cranky old luddite who hates technology, I wouldn't be watching this video. I'm a child of the Space Race.  I love technology.  But I've seen enough changes to know it's always a two edged sword.  And, in the auto industry, designers love to throw technology around for the sake of it, without thought to whether it actually makes things better or not.  There are simple examples of where this has made things worse.  Touch screens should never have been allowed in cars.

There's little doubt in my mind-- watching how all you nutbars drive-- that taking the human element out of driving is going to make things exponentially safer.  No argument there, and this is where the technology might succeed.  But while this video focuses on overcoming user reticence on the basis of safety, that's not the issue where this technology will fail or succeed.  People around the world see their vehicle as an expression of who they are or, more often than not, who they *want to be*.  Good luck overcoming a century of marketing programming of humans.  The only way to make self driving cars truly safe, and realize the full benefit of them safety wise, is to ban people from driving non autonomous vehicles.  Again, good luck with that. 

And here's the kicker.  Many people look to self driving cars as eliminating all the inefficiencies that drivers bring to roads.  So, rush hours won't be so bad, things will run smooth and your commute will be shorter as a result.  Wrong.  Waymo, I am sure, can't wait to sell advertising.  During your work day, you might say to a co-worker "Gee, I haven't eaten at Burger King in a long time."  Your cell phone will give that info to Waymo, and on the way home, you'll be taken by a Burger King or two.  And you'll think 'oh, there must have been an accident on my usual route and this is the most efficient re-route'.  Ha ha ha. No.
We old school drivers have a different view to the younger generation who are happy to hail a taxi in an app which is why Waymo appeals to them more. The laggards will follow.

20 million or 20 billion miles (or hours?) is not very impressive high number of examples for WayMo cars to learn, actually. AI learns way more slowly than humans.  Humans are fast learners by comparison.  Consider supervised learning: ImageNet database has 14 million images divided among 1000 classes, or 14 thousand examples per class on average.  Humans learn what a "cat" is in way less than 14000 examples.  But a computer AI is so slow to learn, that it needs 14 thousand examples to know a cat from a dog!!! Transfer learning reduces new applications to few-shot but that's still borrowing the learning that AI had to do from another computer at the end of the day.  That's supervised learning, the fastest known, which is relatively fast to learn compared to unsupervised learning and reinforcement learning which are much slower, ridiculously slow to learn. Is RI being used by autonomous driving models?  If so then I tell you what, it's not enough to have 20 billion miles of learning in an automated car. You should tell your viewers that humans are super fast learners compared to AI as it stands in 2021. The learning numbers are not the same as if humans drove 20 billion miles.  We really ought not to be impressed by 20 billion simulator miles of reinforcement learning at waymo or any other car maker. AI is dumb as fudge compared to human brains.

Humans are terrible drivers, in good and in bad conditions, so AIs have to pass a very low bar to be safer.

Waymo by all available data already exceeded that bar.

I will preface this by saying that fully autonomous cars are absolutely the future but level 5 autonomy is still a long way off.

The issue that I have with this video is that it draws (currently) invalid parallels to aircraft autonomy. Automated aircraft landings are a much simpler task than navigating icy/snowy roads (traffic is controlled by the tower; position, elevation, and orientation of the runway is known and unchanging). There is a reason why Waymo is doing it's pilot program in Phoenix. Determining how to navigate a vehicle in adverse weather conditions is proving to be a very difficult problem to solve. Radar, lidar, and computer vision all have different edge cases which are difficult to account for.

This video makes it sound as if level 5 autonomy is already here but we are nowhere close.

Excellent video, Derek! The Waymo solution is indeed promising and exciting. I work with AV's (and CCAM in general), and I still see a lot of work to be done in homologation, harmonization, standardization and handling the edge cases, which make up some fraction of a percentage of all traffic situations ‚Äì but is still a significant number. Lvl 4 is like lvl 5 but in restricted ODDs (operational design domains) and full lvl 5 traffic system is a huge leap away from having mixed traffic with lvl 4 units in it.

‚Äã@@-BRODEN well, when people say "big tech" manipulates the cars they're talking about monopolizing them I think. If only google (aka waymo) and other tech giants own the automated driving services, they could set whatever prices they want. Even if you could actually buy the car, you'd be at the whim of these companies continuing support, but they could just as easily add a necessary paid subscription or something, in which case you don't really own it.
But there are several other downsides as well. For example, an often repeated opinion (even in this video) is that automated driving would "solve" traffic problems, but there are plenty of reasons why that might not be the case. Having all cars automated does not reduce the amount of cars on the street, in fact it might increase it, and while they may be a bit faster and that might improve traffic, it's definitely not a solution. Much better tried and tested methods are city planning with walkable spaces in mind and public transportation. The US is particularly bad in this regard, which gives the impression that people will latch on to this idea of autonomous driving *instead* of actual city planning and train networks.
Autonomous driving has its upsides as well, it's not like this video is a complete lie or anything, I believe anyone who tries to argue against the safety they bring is trying to justify themself too much, but it's not as clearly cut and dry as this video implies.

It's strange to talk about autonomous driving without even mentioning Tesla FSD. True, they don't have fully autonomous vehicles regularly travelling without drivers, but they are taking on a much harder problem than Waymo. It's also strange to talk about Waymo autonomous driving without mentioning their main drawback, which is that they rely on externally generated maps and cannot function in an unmapped area (or, indeed, in a mapped area that has significantly changed since the mapping). Waymo has 20 million miles experience, which sounds impressive, but Tesla has data from at least 10 billion miles of regular car driving. Tesla FSD works on unmapped streets. And yes, I mean "works" - it still requires constant driver supervision, but though it still has some kinks that need intervention, it is very, very close and frequently can travel for half an hour and more in city streets with no intervention. Which Waymo can't do in an unmapped area.

Still, the point of the video is correct. Autonomous driving is very close and will be possible most everywhere within years, not decades. At which point we have the elevator problem, which will probably be made worse by media that covers every single autonomous driving incident and ignores the much more common and deadly human caused accidents. Just like electric vehicle fires get lots of press, but gasoline vehicle fires are hardly ever mentioned, despite being much, much more common.

I'm under the impression that Waymo is able to accomplish this because the area of operation of those vehicles was mapped out at least partially manually so the software can manage in those conditions. I'm really excited about this, but I'm still one of the people who think it'll take over 10 years for this to be available in my area. But when it does come, it will save a lot of lives.
