Hey, so‚Ä¶ this is interesting, because there _was_ a glimpse of the infrastructure behind Waymo's driverless vehicles, and you've made much talk about how there are no _humans_ driving the vehicle. Okay, interesting.

But actually, what I'm immediately interested in, was the fact that there are _three_ teams of people who are required to operate these vehicles in, presumably, Arizona. The fact that the vehicles have no drivers on them does not mean that there are _no_ human judgements involved‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâit's just that it's been outsourced, in this case, to a single corporation, who have three teams, at least, working on them (we see Lety's team here, but are there others?). Who make decisions on who dispatches the vehicles, who handles customer service, and, I presume, who will presumably take over in the event of a failure.

_That's_ what I'd like to know. How many vehicles can these three teams handle? How many hours of work do they do a day, a week? Do they get benefits, are there guarantees that they will be trained, and will continue to be trained and qualified for the work that they'll be doing, which is shepherding these fleets of vehicles? Will the solution scale to the problem? What if all 200+ million vehicles in the United States are replaced by autonomous vehicles? How many teams are we talking about here? What happens if they make mistakes or abuse their position? 

You've made big talk about how 94% of accidents in the United States are caused by human error, and that technology by Waymo will drastically reduce that. Maybe. I'd reframe the argument to point out that what widespread adoption of driverless vehicles means is you're placing the responsibility of reducing the six million accidents a year in the United States to a commercial entity, presumably with deep pockets and the ability to dictate how it'll engage with the legal system in the event of something going wrong.

And just to point out‚Ä¶ 6% (i.e., the amount of accidents _not_ attributed to human error) of six million accidents is 360,000. 6% of _that_ , i.e. the percentage of accidents with at least one human fatality, is _at least_ 21,600 dead people. What's the order of magnitude that companies like Waymo are guaranteeing that they'll reduce? Are we talking about reducing the deaths by a thousand times? 21 deaths a year sounds great‚Ä¶ unless you're one of the families affected by those 21 deaths.

Also, another thing‚Ä¶ a comfort you can have with regards to individual citizens being held accountable for their poor driving is that you _can_ subject individual citizens to criminal charges. I would like to point out that the United States Government has _still_ not charged the heads of companies that are responsible for _millions_ of American deaths, for example, Purdue Pharma. What guarantee do we have if Waymo messes up, Americans will be able to hold them accountable? What happens if this technology goes global? How will non-Americans hold American companies accountable if there are deaths? We can't even get the heads of an American corporation to testify, _even_ if they played a role in a _genocide_ . And now you want them to take control of _land-based vehicles_ ?

Sorry, but Derek is way too optimistic here.

Lidar only works in good weather conditions (e.g. heavy fog or water spray from cars in front is deadly), same for cameras. And those ranges of 300m for lidar and 500m for camera sound absolutely unbelievable! Like, pick any sign on a local road, walk 500m away, take a picture and then try to read the sign in the image. You won't. Typical ranges one talks about when using cameras in autonomous driving are like 100-150m max.

Also, you see at least 4 Lidar-Sensors mounted on the car in the video. Has anyone thought about the cost? The 360¬∞ one on top is at least 30,000$, the others probably like half of that each. On top of that you have the 28(!) cameras (some of them with expensive lenses, if they are supposed to come even close to what is claimed) and several radar sensors. The latter typically cost about 1,500$ each. In sum this means that just the sensor equipment costs more than most normal cars! How is this supposed to go into a mass-produced consumer product?

Last point I want to make: energy consumption. With electric cars we are already talking about their comparably low driving range. All of these sensors and especially the GPUs/TPUs and processors needed to make use of the data need a lot, and I really mean *a lot*,  of power. This doesn't go well together at all.
(Before anyone mentions Tesla: They have never used close to this many sensors or had such a high level of automation. And there is a reason why they recently announced that they will exclusively rely on cameras in the future.)

Overall, I must say that this video feels like a big (false) advertisement to me, as harsh as that may sound. Not for Waymo specifically, but autonomous cars in general. Maybe Derek is just a tad too excited about them?

Some points of critique:
- The number of hours of data a system is trained on is not a good measure of how safe the system is. With AI it just tells how ingrained patterns have become and how resistant to changes it now is. Overtraining an AI system is a thing as well, where it will find patterns where there are none and behave erratically. It gives mild confidence that it has seen some edge cases, but the statistic alone gives no confidence that it can handle situations a human *could* handle if they encounter it. An actual list of situations it should pass, and looking through that data if it actually encountered it would be much more useful.
- The statistics about the number of incidents do say something about safety, but only in the environment it has driven. Which, right now, seems to be two places: suburbs outside of Phoenix, Arizona, and in San Francisco and Mountain View, California.
- The point at the beginning of the video that a lot of people think self-driving cars are >10 years away, and that this is not the case because you are riding in one is poorly substantiated. The system is trained on San Francisco, and probably works fine in San Francisco, but that doesn't mean it will translate well to another city in the US, the countryside or another country entirely. This has nothing to do with "badly maintained roads", and more with different scenarios the system has never encountered before. The ability to identify parked cars on the road. The ability to identify when it *should* go with two wheels off-road (which you say it doesn't), because the road is too small for two vehicles to pass. The ability to identify when it cannot go with two wheels off-road and should stop at a part of the road that is a bit wider, designed to let two vehicles pass on a road that is usually too narrow for that. The ability to identify bike roads, where cars are allowed but cyclists can use the entire width of the road. Situations where road rules tell the car that it has right of way, but where human drivers commonly stop to let traffic pass for one reason or another.
- When looking at safety, replacing a random normal car with an autonomous car is not as simple as looking at "is this car safer than the average driver". You also have to look at scalability of the system, and what happens if you have, for example, a 100 of these cars on the same road. Right now, I would assume that these cars actively blind each other with their lidar. I would assume they can handle some data corruption due to that, but it makes the cars less reliable.
- The animation of an intersection where cars just communicate with each other instead of waiting for traffic lights is still a long way away. Such an intersection requires absolute trust between vehicles, because every vehicle on that intersection must know and trust every other vehicle on that intersection to have a plan, and execute that plan exactly as advertised. That would require 100% autonomous cars, and the only way you could trust a car 100% is if they run your software and you know its internal reasoning, or if there is some protocol in place that can handle cases like cars just not communicating. This car is not capable of doing that, and is unlikely to be able to do that in the near future.
- Moral dilemmas do not cease to be moral dilemmas if your average driver is incapable of making the decision in the first place. Waymo's vehicles predict several future scenarios. It will try it's best to get to a destination, and try it's best to avoid collisions while doing so. But it will make decisions based on the data it receives, and those decisions are made by those who tweak the vehicle time after time. And most (moral) dilemmas are not as uncommon as the ones you showcased. For example: Should the car break if a ball-like object bounces on the street, and the car is not predicted to hit it? If a trash can falls over on the street, and it predicts it cannot break to avoid hitting it, should it swerve around it? If a car hits a barrier and bounces into traffic in front of an autonomous car, should it break or swerve? What about if there is a heavy truck behind the car? What about if swerving has the potential for no other collisions to occur? What if that chance is 1%? These decisions have already been made by the people working on Waymo, either by tackling such edge cases or letting the AI network decide on it's own. You have a point that waiting for those moral dilemmas to all be solved before using autonomous vehicles is not going anywhere (we have infinite many of them), but I think you make light of these moral dilemmas. These are moral dilemmas that need to be solved, because it shouldn't be up to the programmers of the vehicle to make that call, or to come up with edge cases to test for.

That said, you make some good points. People are notoriously bad at driving and drive-assist or fully autonomous vehicles can help with that. A large quantity of autonomous vehicles can reduce congestion on highways, because they just automatically drive the same speed as each other and do not swerve left and right all the time. Autonomous vehicles are great for people that cannot or do not want to drive a car, and have to get around in places where there is no or inadequate public transport. I just wished you would have looked in a more critical way at this.

Derek tries to convince us that the "average" human driver is a bad driver, and talks about how humans drive off the road, hit stationary objects, etc. That might all be true, but my suspicion is that a large percentage of these are due to drivers that drive while under the influence, text and drive, drive while sleepy, etc. These skew the distribution of human driver safety to the right. Derek mentions most people think they are above average drivers. I think he is assuming the safety of human drivers follows a bell curve. But if the distribution skews to the right, as I predict it does, then you can have a the mean far below the median, and most people can in fact be better than the mean. If you are a human driver that follows the baseline responsibility guidelines, I'm sure you're above the mean. 

In order for me to be convinced, I need to see self driving driving cars have a lower accident rate per billion miles than the *median* responsible (sober, awake, not texting) human under similar conditions

Living in the Silicon Valley, I've seen a lot of Waymo vans and I've seen them do some pretty impressive things. The most impressive, in my mind, was involving a driver who was hot boxing in their car. It was on a two lane road, I drove up behind the hotboxer and could immediately spot the situation. He was driving slower than traffic and slightly erratic albeit within his lane. The Waymo van pulled up next to me and slowed down refusing to pass the hotboxer, opting to drive below the speed limit until the car turned, at which point the Waymo sped back up to speed and continued on. I spent a long time thinking about what variables in the code must have led it to make that determination. It would seem that if a car is driving below the speed limit and/or exceeding some level of movement within their lane, the algorithm will not pass the car. It could obviously not see that the cabin was full of smoke, so it could only make that decision based on what I would deem to be fairly subtle differences between how a normal driver would drive and how a potential hazard would drive.

Curious question: Why does a self-driving car in Arizona have California license plates? Are they being built and registered in California, and then shipped (or driven) to PHX for their shakedown testing? If there's a possibility a car may be sent back to California, I can see the logic in keeping the plates as is until they're sure, since it's not possible to register an out-of-state car in California until it has 7500 miles on the odometer. In my experience, insurance carriers are also willing to look the other way when people don't immediately transfer their registration as they're supposed to when they move to CA, because they are often in a bind where one law says they have to transfer within 30 days, and another that says they can't until they have 7500 miles.

As someone who works in the industry I need to point out something that is a big barrier to mass adoption of level 5 self-driving vehicles: Sensor cost. Waymo uses their own brand of Lidars called Laser Bear. I don't know the cost on those sensors, but comparable sensors from Velodyne, Ibeo, and Sick cost between $5000 to $60000 PER UNIT. This makes them prohibitively expensive for mass adoption. The current push in the industry seems to be to handle the same task with cameras, radar and ultrasonics which may take awhile to reach true level 5 autonomous

Self-driving cars are going to make a huge positive difference in the world, sooner than most people think, and every day we wait is a lot of damage, pain, and death. Obviously we shouldn't rush things inappropriately, we should make sure each system is significantly better than the average human (with data to prove it) before allowing wide launch, but to wait for perfection is tantamount to murder.

I'm not sure who will get self driving solved first, but I'm glad that there are multiple groups of skilled and dedicated people working on it. I don't know if Waymo's approach of high definition maps with lidar and a team that looks like it has more people than cars will win out, or if Tesla's larger fleet, collecting data from the wild, and using primarily vision (I think they still have ultrasonic sensors, but they've dropped radar and never had lidar) will get there faster. I think either approach can work to be honest.

I'm not convinced that almost full-self driving cars are more dangerous though, even if people pay less attention because they are overconfident. People already pay less attention than we should when driving. The question is whether the probability of a near full self driving car crashing while the pilot isn't paying attention is greater or less than the probability of a non-self driving car crashing while the driver isn't paying attention. Depending on how reliable the self driving system on the car is, the degree to which the pilot has to not pay attention to exceed the non self driving baseline varies greatly. For example, if you just have lane keeping assistance, taking your eyes off the road for even a few seconds is extremely dangerous, if you have Tesla fsd beta (v9 is most up to date right now I think), you are pretty unlikely to have an accident in a few seconds of inattention, even though you should keep paying attention throughout. We don't have good external data on any of these fsd systems (at least none that I've been able to find), but I suspect that people trust it less than they trust themselves when driving, and as a result even partially self driving systems are safer, with the twist that people who have more experience and therefore more trust in the system they use are less attentive and slightly more likely to be in an accident than new users, but still overall less likely to be in a collision than an unassisted driver. I'd really like to see better data on this.

This doesn't actually prove the ">10 years" people wrong.

There is a huge gap between a plane autopilot and a self-driving car. People tend to think about how planes are complex and "deduce" from that that everything about a plane is complex. That just isn't true.

In the operation of a plane, nearly everything of relevance can be measured in nearly-direct ways. Things like pitot tubes, radar, and ILS are all simple enough for an individual or small team to understand thoroughly. They can reliably judge whether the design of the system meets at least a basic standard of soundness. 

The relationship between those measurements and the correct responses can also be readily understood. Much of it is planned by the airlines before they integrate a given model of plane.

These factors come together to mean that a plane autopilot can be thoroughly analyzed by the design team for correctness.

However, active monitoring is still required by the pilots. They need to be able to take control at a moment's notice. This is exactly the standard which Waymo believes a normal person can't be held to.

In a self-driving car, both the measurements of the world (not just "how fast am I going" but also "is that a stop sign?" and such) and the decision-making are much more complicated endeavors that people can't thoroughly design. It is effectively required for machine learning to be used. There are many organizations which know how to create machine learning models, but none that can dig into the model and prove its correctness. It's become a bit of a trend to show how errors in the model can be triggered -- look up "adversarial patch". The only tools for evaluation available for a machine learning model are statistical in nature. How many of the stops signs and non-stop-signs shown to it are correctly identified? No-one is able to confidently say that the data set used to evaluate the model covers every edge-case. Statistical evaluation is an important part of evaluation, but it can't be considered sufficient.

So ultimately, self-driving cars are waiting for machine learning technology to be well-understood. Right now, the technology is widely and somewhat blindly used.

As a programmer and aviation geek I would like to say that making planes fly themselves is far easier than making cars drive themselves, which might sound counterintuitive but think about it. All a plane has to "think" about is flying a direction and an altitude (perhaps following a signal from something like a VOR beacon or ILS approach), that's it. That cat III ILS approach was impressive sure but when it comes down to it all the plane was doing was following a signal to the runway and using ground radar to  determine when to flare (which is admittedly a simplification but you get the gist). 

Also all other traffic announces itself through things like ads-b (the exception being small GA planes and even then they are often equipped) so collision avoidance can (and largely is) automated too, cars do not have that luxury (yet?).

Meanwhile a car has many, many more parameters to take into account which are way more unpredictable too even though they move through 1 less dimension: other drivers (in all types of vehicles from bikes to trucks), pedestrians, animals, traffic signals, road signs, emergency vehicles, the weather obscuring vision,.... the list goes on.


So while under good weather and road conditions and with no unexpected situations his technology currently works it is the millions (if not billions) of edge cases that still throw the technology for a loop. Just look up the videos of a waymo car that runs into a construction zone and froze in the middle of a lane in the middle of traffic, or how it got stuck for 10 minutes trying to navigate a very busy parking lot.
Waymo cars will even take routes that are way longer to avoid certain intersections or to minimize left turns turning a 10 minute ride into one that takes double that.

So yes, level 4 is here and works with the caveat that the weather be nice and no unexpected things happen so IMO it'll be a couple years yet (at least) before true level 5 will be achieved.
But as always, technology often develops exponentially with periods of stagnation followed by leaps forward as breakthroughs are discovered so who knows, I could be completely wrong.

I'm a software tester. I have serious doubts about the industry's code deployment processes, given their move-fast-and-break-things mindset and ideological hatred of regulators -- this is especially true of Tesla. If Waymo makes a software change, how is it tested (virtually and on real streets) before it's deployed to their vehicles? How frequently are those updates made? What regulations is the company willing to accept to ensure that catastrophic bugs don't make it onto the streets? The millions of miles of real-world driving with minimal accidents are great, but how many iterations of the software does that cover? And critically, what weather conditions/traffic density/road-map/etc scenarios do those tests cover? By starting in Arizona, they've chosen the friendliest possible environment and many challenges lay ahead. 

I hate driving, but I agree that people are horrendous drivers who should be torn from the wheel as soon as is practicable. But, I'm deeply skeptical of my industry's ability to deliver and maintain life-saving and -threatening code -- easy enough in the short term, but incredibly difficult long term as teams get bored once a problem is "solved". High-skilled engineers want to run off and work on something new. Management starts squeezing the development teams to do more with less and faster in order to boost their margins, etc. Strong regulation slows things down and adds cost, but it can save lives in the long run.
How well do Waymo's cars in snow? Or on gravel roads? Do they only work in the USA right now, could they handle different colors of road markings or driving on the left?

Nice, but Waymo is NOT an actual "autonomous car".

System is based on "virtual trolley" - the preprogrammed path inside high-definition 3D lidar maps. 

So the car itself is just trying to keep itself in preprogrammed path through static 3D environment and is on watch for irregularities, particularly those moving...

Waymo is NOT capable of driving outside it's preprogrammed path network - that's why it needs to be geofenced and can enter new locations only after special reconnaissance team create detailed 3D map of the area and possible paths.

Technically, in Waymo you are siting in somewhat boring rollercoaster - you can go to any point of the track, but you can't force the car to leave the track...

I'm somewhat disappointed by the video and found it to be a very simplistic take, as well as very american-centric. A lot of the video was dedicated toward human attitudes and behaviour regarding self driving cars, while very little was focussed on technology readiness. Eg. how will the cars handle it if EVERY car is fitted with LIDAR? Surrounded by 100 cars each with multiple LIDARs will it still function or be rendered useless, perhaps something in between with phantom detections?

There was so much nuance that was either brushed over or ignored, attributing poor performance to such throwaway comments as, "in some parts of the world the roads aren't well enough maintained." Meanwhile you're driving round in perfect conditions on very wide American style roads, many of which are dual carriageways. Try that Waymo car on a narrow country road in the UK and see how it does, my bet is that it would cross the lane divider frequently just as Tesla's do too. Self driving cars that are trained on very wide american roads are actually dangerous and not fit for purpose on narrower UK and European roads. They also seem to be averse at making strong control inputs, which means that tight turns and corners are an issue for them, but again not a problem on wide roads with sweeping turns, and all intersections meet at 90 degrees.

I'm not a luddite, and I of course accept that in certain conditions and on certain types of road (essentially dual carriageways and motorways), they are undoubtedly better drivers and never suffer lapses in concentration. However I have not seen anything to suggest that any self driving tech has even come close to driving safely on smaller and more congested roads.

With regards to your poll at 1:20 these options are not mutually exclusive, I am both excited to see a future where they exist and function well, but at the same time I still think it will be >10 years before full unmonitored self-driving is ready.

I agree that hacking into the car is a concern to me for autonomous and even non-autonomous cars that have software controls. I think I read GM is outfitting their cars with a software system for the police to remotely pull over cars. In my mind, it's only a matter of time before those software systems are vulnerable to unethical actors. Blackmail malware has been increasing in recent years, and blackmail over control of your car sounds terrifying.

However, I'm not sure FOSS (free open source software) is a prerequisite for safety. As far as I know, the existing airplane autonomous piloting or elevator systems are not FOSS, but they are generally assumed to be safe regardless. And why "as in freedom"? GNU's definition of free-as-in-freedom mandates the freedom to modify the software. Once these systems are widely adopted, I think having Waymo car running some homebrew homemade software would increase risk. If the homebrew system glitches, drivers around the homebrew car can't tell that it's a custom system to respond accordingly. We absolutely need to audit each autonomous car system and test them to make sure they're safe before mass adoption but after that "free as in freedom" seems like increased risk to me.

So, on perfect roads with ideal weather, it works.  (Presumably they've fixed the driving into the side of the bus thing, I'll assume that for the moment.). But the problem isn't making it work 99% of the time.  It's the 1%...the long tail.

- a sudden downpour in which visibility drops to nearly nil in seconds (what do you do if moving?)
- a construction zone where the old lines have been blacked out, and new ones placed, but at an angle, reflection off both old and new make them look similar, and suddenly it's not clear where the lines are
- a flash flood (happened a few miles down the highway from where I'm sitting)
- whiteout from blowing snow
- 1000 other such things

Judgment, and the ability to improvise, rather than 1000 years of driving history, is a major way to deal with these.

I got enthusiastic about self drive when DARPA stopped holding self drive challenges because the technology was too good...no longer an advanced research topic, in their view, apparently.  And when Google (pre Waymo) published a video of their vehicle sitting things that humans didn't.

But then less so when events showed this to be premature hype, like the car driving into the side of the bus, or a number of seemingly inexcusable Tesla accidents (like not distinguishing that a stopped fire truck wasn't an overhead road sign...say what?  You're at what level of driving?) or driving into the side of a tractor trailer when sunlight blinded.

It'll take more than a drive on a nice day on multi lane roads to convince me.  Show me it driving in a sudden squall, with children piling out of a school, poor lighting, driven rain making the lidar picture more complicated, shopping bags blowing down the street, and maybe a homework assignment amongst those.  Nice day driving may mean that they're one percent of the way there.

I have two main concerns as I live in a mountainous, cold region.
(1) black ice/snow. Although I'm sure a car can receive more weather updates, recognizing and evaluating the road in blizzard/icy conditions isn't as simple as visually looking. An autonomous vehicle in flat, dry, hot Phoenix is going to outperform an autonomous vehicle in Alberta, Boise, or Anchorage. So Phoenix really is a BEST case for autonomy. It's important to understand the WORST cases for autonomous vehicles. Phoenix is also famous for sprawl - the narrow streets and high population density of Seattle, San Fran, Boston or NYC are other "worst cases."  
(2) Old autonomous vehicles. All technologies slow down eventually. The components in the autonomous vehicles will be overused and subject to weather while driving more than most consumer electronics. What happens when a car begins to slow down it's analysis? Does Waymo discontinue use of that vehicle? Because that is probably a very inefficient life-cycle for a vehicle. Constantly getting new vehicles is one of the most environmentally unsustainable practices, and I'm worried that in an abundance of caution for safety the vehicles will be discarded for newer models. I think autonomous vehicles that can have their autonomy "stripped" when they begin to slow down and resold will have a more positive environmental effect by lengthening the life-cycle of the vehicle.

The big hurdle to overcome is people feel safer taking risks if they are in control of those risks. Even if you proved that an autonomous car is safer than the driver it will replace, people will still be apprehensive about getting in that car. That's why it was important for the driverless elevators to have that emergency stop button and why Waymo's vehicles also have an emergency stop button. It gives some level of control back to the user so they FEEL in control without actually being in control.

The plane "flying itself" is supposed to be supported by and closely monitored by pilots. Also, the humans have radar and are talking frequently with air traffic control who have even more radars, pre-approved flight paths/maps that take them safely into and out of the airport and through airspaces, and they can verify with or without the computer by checking in with sensors manually, that they are making a correct flight. When you talked about waymo simulating situation and they said that was equivalent to billions of miles tested, although I agree such testing is useful, it misses two really important points. The real hard corner cases for driving are the ones you cannot predict even with random simulations. You can simulate cars and pedestrians all year, then send out the car and it meets a cow on the road. The other issue is that 90% of self driving is accurate object recognition ie identifying what objects are in the world, what types of objects they are and where they are. Choosing a path once you know where those objects are is actually the easy part. If the car sees something on the road ahead it needs to know is it OK to hit it or not. That requires being able to distinguish a plastic back from a rock, etc. Simulations won't help you here. Only better image recognition trained on a vast set of possible objects and then classifying them into 'its OK/not OK to hit'. Outside the limited areas Waymo drives the hardest part for self driving is dealing with poorly marked roads. It takes a really significant amount of AI training to understand the correct path to take on roads with incorrect/absent marking and/or confusing borders. Waymo is great for limited areas and I can't wait for them to come to an area near me, but they are a long way from handling the sort of driving I do regularly (farm roads)

Read and did a bit of math:
In the US over 3 Trillion miles are driven each year. Approximately 6 million car accidents (of any kind, most are harmless and won‚Äôt even cause significant property damage) happen in that same time frame. So per million miles driven there are approximately 2 accidents.

Waymo with their 20 million miles driven and only 18 accidents, is just below 1 accident per million miles. Or about twice as safe as a human driver. This is also before you account for the fact that the US average includes things like truck drivers driving hundreds of miles a day on the same lonely back highways of the Western US where you barely encounter any cars and thus are incredibly unlikely to crash lowering the collision average significantly compared to urban and suburban areas where Waymo does most of their driving.

So in terms of capabilities I would definitely say we‚Äôre here in terms of self-driving.

Also as a note: Telsa‚Äôs seld-driving options are at most a 2-3 (for regulation purposes they are a 2) on the self-driving scale provided, essentially they are currently more akin to early Waymo examples of people being responsible for the driving and needing to assist the car from time to time, but leaving too much up to the car and getting distracted. So if you have a Tesla, and want to use the feature, keep your eyes on the road.

Derek I look forward to your content because you usually do a great job of being fair and giving the whole picture. I feel that this video has not met the standard of quality we've come to expect from your channel. I understand this was sponsored by Waymo, but to not address the limitations of Lidar technology or even mention the world leader in the self-driving space, Tesla, and their vision only approach seems like a gross oversight. Waymo's 20 million miles is a laughable pittance compared to the billions of real-world miles of data Tesla has.

For those who have no idea what I'm talking about: Lidar is not a scalable solution for self driving. It can only operate in pre-mapped areas and the car is essentially traveling on rails. Compared with Tesla's vision only approach, you could take a Tesla, drop it anywhere on the planet, even if a Tesla has never driven there before and it would drive successfully. This is hugely important and failing to mention it in a video about self-driving cars feels like you're cutting out the approach that is built to serve everyone, not just those living in major cities.

For transparency:  Waymo is owned by Google.  Be very careful about using ANYTHING owned by Google, because they'll definitely be trying to find out more about what you do, where you're going, who you're with, what clothes you're wearing, etc. just so they can sell all that to advertisers.

Waymo works in Phoenix because they have spend countless hours mapping those roads to incredible levels of detail. Plop that car in some random city‚Ä¶it will fail almost certainly. Maybe not in a way that causes an accident, but in a way that requires human intervention. 

If you watch videos of other systems‚Ä¶current autonomous car systems have issues discerning a lot of complex situations and the sensors do not work when obscured‚Ä¶there are a lot of issues that aren‚Äôt worked out.

Autonomous cars are definitely better at driving in ideal conditions‚Ä¶but they are not yet smart enough to discern and work through complex situations that require a level of critical thinking that humans are very good at doing very quickly. In a world where all vehicles are autonomous‚Ä¶yes it would be much better because all vehicles would be communicating with each other. Ok, there are some weird statements in this video. Like comparing traffic to elevators. Isn't it obvious how incredibly more complex car traffic is?
Airplanes have auto-pilot, yes, but have you ever been in a plane without pilot? There are even two pilots in a plane! And I will argue that the scenario of flying a plane is a lot easier to solve for a machine than handling traffic. Auto-pilots in planes do not even use machine learning algorithms to predict any future event. Machine learning and specifically Deep Learning which is used in most of autonomous driving systems, produces models which are inherently unpredictable. It might sometimes be hard to predict the behaviour of other human drivers but at least you can expect some basic human-like decisions, not with AI.
Why do you assume driverless cars are safer than human controlled? There is definitely not enough data to make such a statement. I don't even say that it's not the case, but there is certainly no proof for this anywhere in Waymo's publications (They even state that it is very hard to produce reliable statistics to back such a statement).
You say it is unethical to not replace all cars by autonomous vehicles because lives could be saved? According to the same logic it would be unethical to remove the driver from the autonomous vehicle, because you know what is even safer than a driverless vehicle? A driverless vehicle with a driver as 'backup system'. This is the only form in which autonomous driving should be allowed in my opinion.
 Sorry, but I disagree with many things in this video and the comparisons are terrible. At least, you acknowledged that it is a sponsored video.

the 3 pedestrian accidents involved the waymo being completely stopped, and the pedestrian/bicyclist running into it. That's...so telling about human stupidity. But at that point blaming the waymo would be like blaming a house for a drunk driver crashing into it lol. They really have made some strides in safety though, i live where these run and worked with some former drivers who gave some of the dirt. The accidents involving waymos were almost always either due to the other driver hitting it (like running a red, or just plowing into it because they weren't watching traffic) or because the waymo driver (they still had a backup driver for a long time) screwing up. Like the former driver said they had an incident where the waymo driver fell asleep and turned the wheel, deactivating the automation, and rolled the van (thankfully no passenger or other vehicles were involved). There was an incident where one disgruntled former employee tried to cause wrecks, pulling in front of the waymos and slamming his brakes, and eventually got one to hit him. But police investigated, found the video footage of the dozen+ other times he tried it and failed, and he ended up in jail for it. They really are surprisingly good now, worst case that's happened lately was a funny one where a youtuber who documents all his waymo rides had the car get stuck due to bad construction (they put the cones way too far apart, so the vehicle got confused as to whether the lane was open or closed), and then the support team back at headquarters screwed up in their instructions they pushed to the vehicle which made it worse. So even in that case, it still involved humans making decisions and screwing up. 
So the future of these cars involves a lot, such as proper maintenance of roads, and more uniform rules for construction companies doing road work because we have all seen some really crappy companies that can't put their barricades in place right, or leave lanes too small for most traffic, etc.
I guess it all depends on what we call "fully-autonomous": there are many reasons why Waymo only operates in a little suburb.

Lot to say...I can understand that this video is sponsored by Waymo, but their approach is veryyyy costly and not at all scalable and flexible. One of the big reason behind being expensive is the cost of Lidar ( which definitely will come down over time ) so its not a major concern. The bigger issue is their reliance on hd maps which is not scalable.  Their reliance on hd maps also means that they are not very flexible ( say a spot which previously was empty now has construction ). A huge problem in Machine Learning is the long tail of rare events and you simply cant get those edge cases and train the model for it unless and until you have a huge fleet of cars in diverse conditions sending you feedback. So i am quite certain when autonomous cars become commonplace, Waymo isnt going to be the leader or winner in this segment, it will very very likely be Tesla. Tesla might be over-optimistic on what they promise, but their rate of improvement and fleet size is simply unparalled. That gives them a tremendous advantage.

Waymo has been promising this for 12 years now. They only work in very limited areas with perfect visibility and 100% premapped. I think Tesla has a better chance of solving this that any of these lidar based systems.

As someone with some experience in the field I can confirm that there are multiple companies that already have much better than human autopilot under good driving conditions. The main problems I've seen in the field are older car companies not understanding how to develop software in general and newer companies that overestimate the results that their NN-based solutions get. In both cases you end up with an autopilot that would occasionally catastrophically fail. Waymo knows how to develop software and the hardware they use is complete overkill so it is very expensive but at least guarantees a minimum level of safety. And a lot of it comes down to using the ridiculously expensive but also very reliable LIDAR. Tesla's solution is entirely based on NNs processing camera images which doesn't give you this baseline safety and you can see it in their accidents. The autopilot often fails in trivial situations due to the limitations of NNs. Their whole concept is based on doing what the human brain does but they've skipped the step where the human brain uses simple and hard-wired algorithms to generate 3D data from the two "cameras" we have. A fully autonomous car can be made entirely using cameras but not without simpler and more predictable perception algorithms compared to what Tesla are doing. You don't necessarily need LIDAR, though cheaper LIDAR would be warmly welcomed. And you have to keep in mind that a solution that would lead to most cars on the road being autonomous would mean that the autopilot shouldn't add too much cost to the total cost of the vehicle. And I would say $2000 is a good approximation of this limit. A LIDAR or NN heavy solution cannot get even close to this limit.

TL.DR. Imo we have the technology to easily and cheaply do it, but we are limited by the human error of the people managing these projects.

I will believe L5 autonomous driving is here when self driving cars can drive in and around Boston year round. Phoenix is mostly dry and sunny with wide, obvious roads. I can't imagine Waymo's current lidar working at all after being sprayed with salty slush. We may reach L4 ("full self driving under certain conditions") but "full self driving under all conditions" is way, way off. Today, FSD can play chess but to drive in Boston or similar, challenging environments, it needs to play improvisational jazz.

20 Million miles of data is about a third of what Tesla's cars collect every single day.  (1 million cars x 60 miles per day, average).  Those "simulated" miles are extremely dubious.  Who verifies that what the simulation does is realistic?  Consider a deer crossing the road ahead of you, at night.  How many deer interactions are there in 20 million miles of real world data?   I'd guess maybe a few hundred - but deer interactions are complicated.  How the deer reacts depends not just on it's own desires - but also on the time of day, time of year, the weather, whether there are other cars coming from a different direction, your speed, whether there are baby deer with it's momma, whether it's the rutting season...stuff we can't even imagine.   You simply cannot capture enough deer encounters with 20 million miles of real world data to safely infer what a deer might do - and what your best course of action is.  So you're left with simulation trying to fill in these gaps.   But the behavior of deer is not something that WayMo's simulation engineers know....they just don't.   Sure, you could get a deer biologist "expert" to come in and work on that part - but do THEY even know?   I think not.   But Tesla now have somewhere around 70 BILLION miles of real-world data.  And that's going to include a thousand times more deer encounters than WayMo's dataset.  (Actually, a hell of a lot more than that because WayMo's cars only drive in city centers).   This is the fundamental flaw in WayMo's approach.  Sure, they can capture enough in-town data to build a reasonably safe car - and with only a few hundred cars on the roads, the odds of them encountering something they never saw before is small.  But when you have a few million cars driving on country roads, freeways, in tunnels, in different countries where the rules and driving customs are different - they simply CANNOT capture enough data to do the job.   So, yeah - a WayMo taxi can drive you around some small downtown area - but ask it to drive you from El Paso, Texas to Sheboygan Wisconsin  (as my Tesla recently drove me) - it's going to see VASTLY  more things than they have data for...and they can't fix that.  They'd need a million cars on the road (which WayMo can't afford) - each one covered in their sensors (which are EXPENSIVE - so they won't pursuade large car makers to install them unnecessarily for a few years before the software will work).   This is a serious problem - and I don't see how anyone other than a large car maker with the motivation to spend the money on it can possibly make this work...outside of some tiny, heavily constrained area.
